expose reasons why the different levels of sensitivity provided an ad-
vantage over rival organisms who had less, thus providing a way of answer-
ing (or sidestepping) the creationist quip, “What use is half an eye?”
It has taken more than a century of research on a wide variety of organisms
to demonstrate that Darwin’s hunch was basically right. Appearances to the
contrary, organs and structures sensitive to light can be assembled piecemeal,
with the intermediates enjoying some advantage over t
